doc.title: Growth won't be Swift
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-28/Growth wont be SwiftGrowth wont be Swift_2025-08-28

passages.text: Aroundtown-Grand City

Both Aroundtown and Grand City reported valuation gains during H1, bringing headline LTV significantly below policy limits. While both landlords plan to grow, we do not expect move to be swift as EPRA LTV remain high and refinancing is expected to decrease ICR. We remain UW.

We have seen significant compression in real estate spreads over the past couple of years, and some of the high- beta landlords such as Aroundtown and Grand City are trading near historically low spread levels. Even though the headline LTV for Aroundtown is below the policy limit of \(45\%\) , we think leverage (including hybrids) is too high, and the material refinancing needs could be a drag on ICR in the future. While Grand City has significantly reduced its leverage over past couple of years, Aroundtown owns \(62\%\) of the company's shares, and we think it will continue to influence the strategy of Grand City. We remain cautious about the growth plans of the company and reiterate our Underweight rating on both Aroundtown and Grand City.

Both Aroundtown and Grand City don't seem to be in a hurry to refinance their NC26 hybrids ahead of the call date (Figure 2). While they expect refinancing conditions to improve to allow them for a call and replace of the instruments, they don't shy away from highlighting their opportunistic stance, commenting that decision will be based on prevailing market conditions. Given the material refinancing needs for Aroundtown, we think its in their interest to behave in a bondholder- friendly manner with regard to their NC26 hybrids. We recommend following trade ideas:

- Switch from ARNDTN 7.125% NC30 to ARNDTN 1.625% NC26 to take out 10 points in cash price.- Switch from ARNDTN 5% NC29 to ARNDTN 7.078% stub at similar cash price but benefiting from a much higher coupon and reset spreads, at the expense of reduced liquidity.

This document is intended for institutional investors and is not subject to all of the independence and disclosure standards applicable to debt research reports prepared for retail investors under U.S. FINRA Rule 2242. Barclays trades the securities covered in this report for its own account and on a discretionary basis on behalf of certain clients. Such trading interests may be contrary to the recommendations offered in this report.
Please see analyst certifications and important disclosures beginning on page 5. Completed: 28- Aug- 25, 07:06 GMT Released: 28- Aug- 25, 07:10 GMT Restricted - External
FIGURE 1. Z-spreads (bp) over remaining maturity
Source: Bloomberg, Barclays Research
FIGURE 2. Hybrids' yield to reset to time to reset
Source: Bloomberg, Barclays Research

In seniors, we prefer logistics names such as Logico (Portfolio recycling, 26 February 2025, Overweight) and PTHREE (Disposals to fund developments, 10 March 2025, Overweight), or diversified landlords such as Castellum (Fastighets AB Balder/Castellum AB: Initiation of coverage - Mixed signals, 26 August 2025). We recommend following trade ideas:

- Switch from ARNDTN 1.45% 28s to LOGICR 3.25% 28s to pick up 10bp in z-spread, or switch from ARNDTN 4.8% 29s to LOGICR 4.25% 29s at flat z-spread.- Switch from GYCGR 4.375% 30s to PTHREE 4.625% 30s to pick up 15bp in z-spread or CASTSS (Market Weight) 4.125% 30s to pick up 30p in z-spread.

Aroundtown reported a like- for- like (llf) revaluation gains of \(1.4\%\) on its portfolio during H1 25. The positive revaluation gains helped the company to reduce headline and EPRA LTV by 1pp each during Q2 25, to \(40\%\) and \(58\%\) , respectively. The portfolio rental yield decreased by 10bp, to \(5\%\) , during the first half. The company reported a lfl rental growth of \(3\%\) on its portfolio and EPRA vacancy remained stable at \(7.5\%\) during the quarter. The average cost of debt increased by 10bp, to \(2.1\%\) , while the ICR declined to \(4.2x\) from 4.3x during Q2 25. There were significant changes in the Aroundtown senior management. Deputy CFO Jonas Tintelnot replaced the current CFO Eyal Ben David. Kamaldeep Manaktala (CEO of hotels division) has been promoted to deputy CEO of the company.
FIGURE 3. ARNDTN-GYCGR reported metrics as of H1 25
Source: S&P, Barclays Research
FIGURE 4. Debt-maturity profile as of H1 25 (€bn)
Source: Company reports, Barclays Research

Grand City reported a like- for- like (lfl) revaluation gains of \(1.6\%\) on its portfolio during H1 25. The headline LTV remained unchanged at \(32\%\) , whereas the EPRA LTV decreased by 1pp to \(44\%\) during Q2 25. The portfolio rental yield remained unchanged at \(4.9\%\) during the first half. The company reported a lfl rental growth of \(3.7\%\) on its portfolio and EPRA vacancy improved by 10bp, to \(3.7\%\) , during the quarter. The average cost of debt remained stable at \(1.9\%\) , while the ICR declined to \(5.4x\) from 5.5x during Q2 25.

Aroundtown reported a consolidated cash and liquid asset balance of €3.37bn at the end of June 2025. Of this €3.37bn liquidity, €1.48bn is held in the Grand City entity, which is more than sufficient to cover all of Grand City's 2025/26/27 debt maturities (Figure 4). However, We think Aroundtown still needs more cash to cover its own 2026/27 debt maturities (AROUNDTOWN SA: Prioritising refinancing over disposals, 28 May 2025). Hence, We expect Aroundtown to remain active in the new issue market. We think Grand City may also utilise the conducive bond market to further push out debt maturities and to continue to maintain strong liquidity position.

Aroundtown closed disposals of c. €400mn assets during H1 2025, of which c. €125mn was from Grand City entity. After having disposed over €10bn of gross assets since 2020, Aroundtown is switching back into growth mode. Both Aroundtown and Grand City made comments around pursuing external growth opportunities and entering new geographies including America and GCC. While we think Grand City has the balance sheet to pursue these opportunities, we think leverage is still high for Aroundtown (EPRA LTV of \(58\%\) ). Moreover, the company also talked about potential dividend payments for FY25, which may also add to its leverage.
Bloomberg Pan-European Credit IndexOldNewEuropean HG Financial OtherUnderweightUnderweightAROUNDTOWN SAUnderweightUnderweightGRAND CITY PROPERTIES SAUnderweightUnderweightSource: Barclays Research

I, Neeraj Kumar, CFA, hereby certify (1) that the views expressed in this research report accurately reflect my personal views about any or all of the subject securities or issuers referred to in this research report and (2) no part of my compensation was, is or will be directly or indirectly related to the specific recommendations or views expressed in this research report.
AROUNDTOWN SA, Underweight, CD/J

Valuation Methodology: Even though the headline LTV for Aroundtown is below the policy limit of \(45\%\) , we think leverage (including hybrids) is too high, especially given the material refinancing needs. We think the company will need to keep accessing the bond market to refinance debt maturities ahead of time. We remain cautious about the growth plans of the company.

Risks that May Impeach Achievement of the Rating: On the upside, if Aroundtown is able to sell assets in material volumes, capitalizing on valuation gains, or raise equity, it could driver further tightening in the bonds. The company could also tender for bonds with its cash position.
Representative Bond: ARNDTN 1.45 07/09/28 (EUR 95.59, 26- Aug- 2025)
GRAND CITY PROPERTIES SA, Underweight, CD/FA/J

Valuation Methodology: Given its \(62\%\) ownership stake, ARNDTN has the ability to significantly influence the strategy of GYCGR, exposing investors to governance risks, beyond the financial risks of GYCGR on a standalone basis. When it comes to capital markets actions, we expect GYCGR to continue to act in line with Aroundtown. However, we expect Grand City to fare better than Aroundtown on operational grounds.
Risks that May Impeach Achievement of the Rating: On the upside, issuer could pursue LME at the short end of the curve, which could driver further tightening in the bonds.

Sectors in U.S. High Grade Research are defined using the sector definitions of the Bloomberg U.S. Credit Index and are rated against the Bloomberg U.S. Credit Index.

Sectors in U.S. High Yield Research are defined using the sector definitions of the Bloomberg U.S. High Yield 2% Issuer Capped Credit Index and are rated against the Bloomberg U.S. High Yield 2% Issuer Capped Credit Index.
Sectors in European High Grade Research are defined using the sector definitions of the Bloomberg Pan- European Credit Index and are rated against the Bloomberg Pan- European Credit Index.

Sectors in Industrials and Utilities in European High Yield Research are defined using the sector definitions of the Bloomberg Pan-European High Yield \(3\%\) Issuer Capped Credit Index excluding Financials and are rated against the Bloomberg Pan-European High Yield \(3\%\) Issuer Capped Credit Index excluding Financials.

Sectors in Financials in European High Yield Research are defined using the sector definitions of the Bloomberg Pan-European High Yield Finance Index and are rated against the Bloomberg Pan-European High Yield Finance Index.

Sectors in Asia High Grade Research are defined on Barclays Live and are rated against the Bloomberg EM Asia USD High Grade Credit Index. Sectors in Asia High Yield Research are defined on Barclays Live and are rated against the Bloomberg EM Asia USD High Yield Corporate Credit Index.

Sectors in EEMEA and Latin America Research are defined on Barclays Live and are rated against the Bloomberg EM USD Corporate and Quasi Sovereign Index. These sectors may contain both High Grade and High Yield issuers.

This means there are different ways to evaluate a company or an investment and so different values may be placed on certain sustainability credentials as well as adverse ESG- related impacts of companies and ESG controversies. The evolving nature of sustainable investing considerations, models and methodologies means it can be challenging to definitively and universally classify a company or investment under a sustainable investing label and there may be areas where such companies and investments could improve or where adverse ESG- related impacts or ESG controversies exist. The evolving nature of sustainable finance related regulations and the development of jurisdiction- specific regulatory criteria also means that there is likely to be a degree of divergence as to the interpretation of such terms in the market. We expect industry guidance, market practice, and regulations in this field to continue to evolve.
